review.title: Causality-Aided Falsification
review.abstract: Falsification is drawing attention in quality assurance of heterogeneous systems whose complexities are beyond most verification techniques' scalability. In this paper we introduce the idea of causality aid in falsification: by providing a falsification solver -- that relies on stochastic optimization of a certain cost function -- with suitable causal information expressed by a Bayesian network, search for a falsifying input value can be efficient. Our experiment results show the idea's viability.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In computer science, verification refers to the task of providing mathematical proof for asserting that the behavior of a system M fulfills a desired characteristic (called a specification) under all circumstances (such as choosing the input formula for the system M). However, mathematical proof gives a degree of confidence that is fundamentally different from empirical guarantees provided by testing. Extensive research efforts have yielded a number of effective verification techniques and they have seen successful applications in the real world. At the same time, however, it is also acknowledged that heterogeneous systems on a large scale are still beyond the scalability of most of these verification techniques. Noteworthy among these are Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs), which have not only discrete digital dynamics, but also continuous physical dynamics. Imagine a car today: it contains not only dozens of chips (such as ECUs), but also continuous dynamics of internal dynamics (etc.).

sections.heading: 6 Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we show that causality information in the form of a Bayesian network helps us to solve falsification problems efficiently, but we still face many challenges in building such helpful Bayesian networks. As we discussed in paragraph 1, we expect the probabilistic programming language theory to shed light on the problem, but in any case, we need more practical sample scenarios to evaluate the feasibility of our approach. Furthermore, we assume that our algorithm proposed in paragraph 4 has the potential for many improvements. As we note in paragraph 2.2.2, the acquisition function in GP-PSat is simple but not state-of-the-art in the field of Gaussian process optimization. Extending our approach to other types of acquisition functionality is not easy, but we believe it is possible.
